content:
Damn, this is a nice clash.

First it seems easy, then a bit harder when you see the notation, then a LOT harder when you realise you'll hit stack/memory issues with the size of the factorials you're calculating, then a lot easier if you can figure out the trick to avoiding this issue...

I ended up giving up in my clash because it was fastest mode and I didn't think I had enough time to solve it once I realised my naive approaches weren't going to work.

I think it would be really good to mention a hint in the statement that the factorials will get VERY large and that naive approaches will hit memory limits. Otherwise clashers will likely go through the same issues as me and not have enough time to re-work their solution when they realise the issue.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Exercice sympa où, pour une fois, il ne faut pas réfléchir à une solution algorithmique complexe mais simplement utiliser le bon type.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Special for math lovers...

Output
* Please move all the explanation and examples to Goal section, and then just write a one-line simple description in this section.

Goal (after changing per above)
* (For the output format only) Please change "*10^" to "{{*10^}}".

* Please change "(float)" to "[[float]]" (3 times).

* Please change "(exponent)" to "[[exponent]]" (twice).

* Please change "if necessary, float should be rounded to the closest 2-decimal float" to "[[float]] should be rounded to and shown with 2 decimal places."

* Please change "get rounded" to "gets rounded".

Thanks.

where is the Goal section ? I cannot find it even with Ctrl+F
everything else has been updated

Thanks for enjoying !
Numbers getting extremly large is already hinted by the constraint on n (can be as high as 65,536, and factorials are no joke)

Yeah, but the constraints are the last section before the tests, so it's easy to not notice them in a clash.

I think it would be kinder to have it in the statement, personally. Like below:
"<<Hint>>: The later tests will get VERY big, too big to store as an integer."

Up to you, of course.
It's the statement. After you exit Edit mode, it's shown under the heading "Goal".

oh right
thanks for the feedback, everything should be updated now.
